Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract: Using Field Experiments to Identify Barriers to Labor Market Success and Human Capital Accumulation

This project aims to identify barriers preventing workers from succeeding in the labor market: in particular, barriers that prevent workers from demonstrating their skills to potential employers and barriers that prevent workers from gaining important skills. The first project examines a Catch 22 that new labor market entrants face: it's difficult for them to get a job without prior experience, but it's difficult to get experience without a prior job. This project tests whether providing more information to employers about workers' aptitudes can improve their labor market outcomes by making employers more willing to hire them. The second project examines a Catch 22 that displaced workers face. Because employers use unemployment as an adverse signal of worker ability, the longer workers are out of work, the harder it becomes for them to find a job. This project tests whether helping workers fill in their resume gaps with short-term, part-time employment or volunteering can improve their labor market outcomes.
While the first two projects test for the importance of information barriers in labor markets, the third tests the importance of a simple resource barrier. Despite the fact that advanced high school classes have been linked to better subsequent outcomes, many low-income high school students do not have access to advanced classes at their high schools. Online classes have been proposed as one way to fill this resource gap. This project examines whether providing students with access to advanced online classes can improve their subsequent educational outcomes. It also analyzes how the effects of these online classes compare to the effects of in-person versions of the same classes.

The intellectual merit of this agenda lies in applying rigorous experimental evidence to answer these questions. All three projects utilize randomized field experiments. These projects should improve our understanding of labor markets and educational settings. For example, there is a long theoretical literature on employer learning about worker abilities, but less empirical evidence on how different signals affect employers' beliefs and worker outcomes. Similarly, there is a lot of speculation about the ability of online classes to improve students' access to high-quality education, but less empirical evidence on this topic. The broader impacts of this agenda lie in identifying policies and practices that can improve the labor market outcomes of disadvantaged groups. A priority of this agenda is to disseminate the results of the research to practitioners and policy-makers and to train students to conduct high-quality research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to use field experiments to identify barriers that prevent workers from succeeding in the labor market. Here, I discuss projects that focus on two such barriers.

In “‘Acting Wife’: Marriage Market Incentives and Labor Market Investments,” (published in the American Economic Review) Leonardo Bursztyn, Thomas Fujiwara and I hypothesize that the marriage market presents single women with a tradeoff. Men prefer romantic partners who are less ambitious, educated, and successful than they are. Thus, actions that may help women in the labor market (e.g., speaking up in meetings or working long hours) may hurt women in the marriage market. Through two experiments, a survey, and analysis of existing data, we find that single women do respond to this tradeoff, making themselves less appealing to the labor market.

Motivated by the idea that women may sacrifice earnings for more flexible work arrangements, Alexandre Mas and I estimate workers’ preferences for these arrangements in “Valuing Alternative Work Arrangements,” (published in the American Economic Review). We ask job applicants to choose between different jobs, for example a standard Monday to Friday, 9 am to 5 pm job paying $16 per hour and flexible-schedule job paying $15 per hour. Observing how workers’ choices vary with the jobs’ wages tells us how much money workers are willing to give up for a given amenity. The majority of workers do not value the ability to choose their schedules or the number of hours they work. However, some workers value these substantially. The average worker is willing to give up 8% of wages for the option to work from home (pre-COVID-19). Workers dislike having an unpredictable schedule set by an employer, a common arrangement for retailers, and are willing to give up 20% of their wages to avoid this. This is in large part due to an aversion to working evenings and weekends. Women and women with young children value working from home and avoiding employer-chosen schedules even more strongly. Nevertheless, women are not differentially likely to be in these jobs.

In “Alternative Work Arrangements” (published in the Annual Review of Economics) Alexandre Mas and I investigate several puzzles raised by this paper. First, if women value these seemingly family-friendly job characteristics more, why aren’t they more likely to be in jobs that have them? We find that while women value working from home all else equal, jobs with location flexibility are actually less family-friendly on average: they are more stressful, interfere with family life more often, and have a higher probability of requiring late hours. This seems to be because workers that have more control over their working conditions also have more responsibility over their output. Instead, the primary way that women seem to achieve more family-flexible schedules is by taking jobs with fewer hours, including part-time jobs.  

Second, given that many workers value flexible arrangements (all else equal), a simple model would suggest that these arrangements should have become more prevalent as information technology decreased the costs of allowing workers to work from home or at non-standard times. In “Alternative Work Arrangements” we find that, contrary to popular belief, flexible work arrangements have not become much more common over time (before COVID-19). We explore several hypotheses for this puzzle. For example, one worker's choice to work from home may negatively impact other workers or working from home may make monitoring employees more difficult.  

This project also focused heavily on the education plan. I designed and taught a new class on field experiments for undergraduate students, which culminated with them designing their own experiments. This class reached students typically under-represented in economics: most students in the class were women, and a majority of the class was under-represented minorities. 

The project has provided opportunities for many students to learn more about research in economics and gain exposure to large field experiments. These include seven students who worked on the project as graduate students at Harvard University and seven students who worked on the project between college and graduate school, many of whom were women and students of color. During this project, I advised many Ph.D. and undergraduate students at Harvard University and spoke on a variety of panels for graduate students including those aimed at women and under-represented minorities.

I also disseminated the results of this project widely. I gave talks on this project to academic audiences as well as practitioners and wrote more accessible pieces to disseminate the research to the public.
